questions.text: A 10 year old female patient presents with a history of severe sunburn after only a few minutes in sun. On examination there were freckling in sun exposed areas, dry skin and skin pigmentation. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in genes responsible for nucleotide excision repair.

It is characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) light, leading to severe sunburns after minimal sun exposure.

The condition is characterized by severe photosensitivity, skin pigmentary changes- Freckles, Poikiloderma, malignant tumor development, and occasionally progressive neurologic degeneration.

Patients often develop freckling, dry skin, and skin pigmentation changes in sun-exposed areas.

Option B: Bloom syndrome:
Bloom syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, photosensitivity, and a predisposition to cancer, but it typically does not present with the same severity of sunburn or freckling seen in XP.

Option C: Warts:
Warts, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), are benign skin lesions that do not present with the severe sun sensitivity or freckling associated with XP.

Option D: Melanocytic nevus:
A melanocytic nevus (mole) is a benign growth of melanocytes and does not explain the extreme photosensitivity, dry skin, or systemic implications seen in this patient.

Key Takeaway:

Xeroderma pigmentosum -AR disorder

Mutation in Nucleotide excision repair gene

severe photosensitivity, skin pigmentary changes- Freckles, Poikiloderma

questions.text: A baby is born with a membrane around him at the time of birth. Which of the following conditions is depicted?
questions.solution:
Lamellar ichthyosis (LI) is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by the presence of a collodion membrane at birth. This membrane is a tight, clear sheath that typically dries and peels off in the first few weeks of life, revealing scaly skin beneath. Affected infants often have large, dark, plate-like scales

Option A: Ichthyosis vulgaris:
Ichthyosis vulgaris is a common inherited skin disorder that typically manifests in early childhood, characterized by dry, scaly skin but does not present with a collodion membrane at birth.

Option C: X-linked ichthyosis:
X-linked ichthyosis is caused by a deficiency of steroid sulfatase and primarily affects males. It does not typically present with a collodion membrane at birth, and associated features include preauricular skin tags and undescended testes.

Option D: Hyperkeratosis:
It refers to an excessive thickening of the outer layer of the skin, which can occur in various conditions, but it does not specifically describe the collodion membrane or the presentation at birth seen in lamellar ichthyosis.

Key takeaway:

Lamellar ichthyosis

Autosomal recessive

Collodion membrane at birth, later develops large, dark, plate-like scales

questions.text: A 28 year old male presented with multiple nodular lesions all over body. There was palmar and axillary freckling. Family history was positive in father. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Patient in the image is showing multiple neurofibromas and Palmar freckling.
  • Family history in father is also positive pointing towards diagnosis of NF-1
  • NF 1 is also known as Von recklinghausen's disease

Option A- Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder of multisystem hamartomatosis

It contains-

  • Epilepsy
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Mental retardation

It is also known as EpiLoiA

Epi- Epilepsy

Loi- Low IQ

A- Adenoma sebaceum

Other cutaneous manifestations include ash leaf macule, shagreen patch, and periungual fibroma

Option C- Darier disease is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder classified as a hereditary acantholytic dermatosis. Darier disease typically presents with scaly crusted papules in a seborrhoeic distribution and in skin folds.

Option D- Cowden disease

A rare inherited disorder marked by the presence of many benign growths called hamartomas and an increased risk of cancer.

Key takeaway:

Neurofibromatosis - AD disorder

Neurofibroma, CAfe au lait macules, lisch nodules, freckles in axilla & groin

Family history

questions.text: A 14 year old male patient presented with skin lesions over face since 10 years. On cutaneous examination there was rough thickened skin patch over lower back. There was nodule in periungual fold. Family history was present in father. Which triad is seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Vogt's triad

It is seen in tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder of multisystem hamartomatosis 

It contains-

  • Epilepsy
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Mental retardation

It is also known as EpiLoiA

Epi- Epilepsy

Loi- Low IQ

A- Adenoma sebaceum


Option B: Follicular occlusion triad

It is a triad of acne conglobata, hidradenitis suppurativa, and dissecting cellulitis of the scalp.

Option C: Hutchinson's triad

It represents the stigmata of congenital syphilis characterized by interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson's teeth (peg-shaped, notched permanent incisors), and eighth-nerve deafness.

Option D: Meltzer's triad

The classic presentation of mixed (types II and III) cryoglobulinemia is characterized by triad of recurrent showers of dependent palpable purpura, asthenia, and arthritis or arthralgia

Key takeaway:

Tuberous sclerosis- autosomal dominant disorder of multisystem hamartomatosis

It contains- Epilepsy, Facial angiofibroma, Mental retardation

questions.text: What nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic, eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of the hands?
questions.solution:
Pellagra is a systemic disease caused by vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It is

characterized by the 4 D's - dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia and, if untreated,

death.

Dermatitis over photoexposed site of body. eczematous lesions over neck also known as 'casal's necklace'. (Choice B)


Pellagra is a disease of a maize and jowar-eating population.Amino-acid imbalance caused by an excess of leucine is the cause of pellagra in both jowar and maize eaters. Excess of leucine appears to interfere in the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

Etiology:

  • Malabsorption syndromes (jejunoileitis, gastroenterostomy, subtotal gastrectomy, Crohn's disease),
  • Chronic alcoholism,
  • Metabolic derangements (Hartnup disease, carcinoid syndrome), and
  • Drugs (INH, 6-mercaptopurine, 5-fluorouracil, pyrazinamide, phenytoin, chloramphenicol, azathioprine, phenobarbitone, ethionamide)

Option A- Vit B1 deficiency leads to Beriberi

Option C- Vit D deficiency lead to rickets, osteomalacia

Option D- Vit C deficiency leads to scurvy

Key Takeaway:

  • Pellagra caused by vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.
  • 4 D's - dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia and, if untreated, death.
  • Chronic Alcoholic

questions.text: A 3 year old female presented with skin lesions as shown in the image. There was a history of diarrhea. Which mineral deficiency can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare disorder associated with zinc deficiency. It presents with the classic triad of:

  • Peri-acral and periorificial dermatitis
  • Diarrhea

Option B- Iron deficiency leads to anemia

Option C- Vit C deficiency leads to scurvy

Option D- Vit A deficiency leads to xerosis, phrynoderma,xerophthalmia, night blindness

Key Takeaway:

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica Presentation: Pediatric age
  • Zinc Deficiency
  • Classic triad of Peri-acral and periorificial dermatitis, Diarrhoea, Alopecia.

questions.text: A female with BMI>30 presented to the dermatology OPD with lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
The image is showing hyperpigmented velvety lesions present over neck suggestive of acanthosis nigricans.

Etiology-

  • Obesity (here BMI greater than 30)
  • Drugs - Protease inhibitors, nicotinic acid
  • Endocrine cause (PCOD, HAIRAN syndrome- Hyperandrogenism, Insulin resistance, Acanthosis nigricans)
  • Malignancy (G adenocarcinoma)

Mechanism:

Increased circulating insulin

IGF activation

Keratinocytes, dermal fibroblast proliferation

Key takeaway:

Metabolic syndrome, characterized by a constellation of metabolic abnormalities, including central obesity, insulin resistance, hypertension, and dyslipidemia, poses a significant risk for the development of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases and type II diabetes mellitus.

The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome necessitates the presence of 3 or more of these metabolic abnormalities.

questions.text: A 6 year old girl presenting with rough surfaced lesions over her elbow, knees also had impaired night vision. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows follicular keratotic lesions over elbows.

The patient also had night vision. Suggestive of Vit A deficiency.


Phrynoderma is a form of follicular hyperkeratosis associated with nutrition deficiency

Phrynoderma is associated with nutritional deficiency, particularly:

  • vitamin A deficiency(commonly)
  • Severe malnutrition
  • Vitamin E and B deficiency
  • Essential fatty acid deficiency

Treatment: Vitamin A replacement (50,000-150,000 U/day for 1-4 months, supplemental linoleic acid using safflower or linseed oil

Option A- Keratosis pilaris characteristically presents with papules with follicular involvement and surrounding erythema typically located on the extensor surfaces of the proximal upper and lower extremities.

Option C-Darier disease, previously known as keratosis follicularis, is a genodermatosis inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. This rare disease classically features multiple red or brown papules with hyperkeratosis, nail abnormalities (eg, longitudinal erythronychia), and mucosal changes

Option D- Folliculitis is a common, skin condition in which the hair follicle becomes infected/inflamed and forms a pustule or erythematous papule of overlying hair-covered skin

Key takeaway:

Phrynoderma- Vit A,B,E and essential fatty acid deficiency

Symptoms- Follicular papules over elbow and knee and xerosis

questions.text: A 45 year old diabetic patient presents with asymptomatic skin lesion as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Granuloma annulare (GA) is the most common non-infectious granulomatous disease.

  • Presentation: Typically appears as erythematous plaques or papules arranged in an annular (ring-like) configuration.
  • Location: Often found on the lateral and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet.
  • Usually asymptomatic,

Option A. Herald patch: Indicates Pityriasis rosea, which features a large initial patch followed by smaller lesions. It is not typically asymptomatic.

Option C. Tinea corporis: Presents as annular erythematous itchy lesions with scaling, showing active margins and central clearing. This would usually be symptomatic.

Option D. Erythema annulare centrifugum: Characterized by annular, erythematous lesions that expand centrifugally and may have a trailing scale. It typically has a more inflammatory appearance.

Key Takeaway:

  • Granuloma annulare is a non-infectious condition often seen in patients with diabetes and characterized by its distinct annular appearance.
  • Location: Often found on the lateral and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet.
  • Usually asymptomatic

questions.text: A 42 year old PLHA male presented with skin lesion all over body since 7 days and oral and genital lesions since 6 days . He was prescribed some medicine for pain in abdomen before 10 days. There was no history of similar lesions in past. On examination, there were multiple dusky erythematous macules which become confluent and peeling of skin noted over back , bilateral upper and lower limb. Which of the following criteria is not included in SCORTEN?
questions.solution:
Serum Bicarbonate less than 20 mmol / L is component of SCORTEN Criteria.

Option A: Serum Urea > 10 mmol/l is part of SCORTEN Criteria.

Option B: Serum glucose > 14 mmol/L is part of SCORTEN Criteria.

Option D: Heart rate > 120 bpm is part of SCORTEN criteria.

Key Takeaway:

SCORTEN Criteria:

- Age > 40 years

- BSA > 10 % on Day 1

- Bicarbonate < 20 mmol / L

- Cancer

- Glucose Level > 14 mmol / L

- Heart Rate > 120 bpm

- Urea level > 10 mmol / L

questions.text: 16 year old woman presented to emergency for severe skin peeling affecting more than 30% BSA. The patient was recently prescribed Trimethoprim- sulfamethoxazole for UTI. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Steven Johnson Syndrome is diagnosed when 10% BSA is involved.

Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) is a rare, life-threatening skin condition that often results from an allergic reaction to certain medications. It causes severe blistering and peeling of the skin, often affecting the mucous membranes of the eyes,mouth, and genitals.

Causes

  • Medication: The most common cause of SJS is an adverse reaction to medication, especially:
    • Anticonvulsants (drugs used to treat seizures)
    • Antimicrobials (antibiotics and antifungals)
    • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
    • Allopurinol (used to treat gout)
  • Infections: Less commonly, SJS can be triggered by infections, such as mycoplasma pneumonia.

Symptoms

  • Flu-like symptoms: Fever, fatigue, sore throat, cough
  • Skin rash: Initially a target-like rash, followed by blisters and peeling skin
  • Mucous membrane involvement: Painful sores in the mouth, eyes, and genitals

Treatment

  • Discontinuation of the offending medication: If identified, the medication causing the reaction must be stopped immediately.
  • Supportive care: Treatment focuses on managing pain, preventing infections, and maintaining fluid balance.
  • Hospitalization: Due to the severity of SJS, patients often require hospitalization for intensive care.

Option B: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis is diagnosed when > 30% BSA is involved.

Option C: SJS-TEN overlap is diagnosed when 10% to 30% BSA is involved.

Option D: Erythema Multiforme is cutaneous and mucosal hypersensitivity reaction mostly Caused by HSV.

Key Takeaway:

SJS- < 10% BSA

TEN- > 30% BSA

SJS-TEN overlap- 10% to 30% BSA

questions.text: A 34 year old male presented with complaints of burning and itching over the thigh with skin lesions. There was a history of painkiller tablet consumption before 1 day. Similar history of skin lesion over the same site before 2 years. The condition shown in the image is_
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Fixed drug eruption. It occurs at the same site on repeat exposure of drugs. It is common due to NSAIDS.

Fixed drug eruption is Type VI Hypersensitivity reaction.

Causative Drugs: NSAIDs, Cotrimoxazole, Tetracyclines.

Morphology:

  • Circular dusky plaque.
  • Recurs at the same site (FIXED).
  • Heals with a very characteristic hyperpigmentation.

Treatment: Discontinuation of Drugs.

Option A: Tinea corporis is erythematous scaly annular lesions caused by dermatophyte infection. It is associated with itching.

Option B: Granuloma annulare is a common inflammatory skin condition typified clinically by annular, smooth, discolored papules and plaques, and necrobiotic granulomas on histology.

Option C: BT leprosy lesions are erythematous asymmetric plaques with satellite lesions associated with decreased touch temperature sensation over plaque.

Key Takeaway:

Fixed drug eruption:

Type VI Hypersensitivity reaction.

Drugs: NSAIDs, Cotrimoxazole, Tetracyclines.

Morphology:

  • Circular dusky plaque.
  • Recurs at the same site (FIXED).
  • Heals with a very characteristic hyperpigmentation

questions.text: A child presented with a sore throat and fever and was prescribed a medicine, after which he followed up with this rash. Which is the causative drug?
questions.solution:
The image shows erythematous maculopapular rash over the trunk.

Ampicillin rash:

In 5- 10% patient

Association- Infectious mononucleosis (fever + Sore throat + Cervical / neck swelling)

Other association- Lymphocytic leukemia

Clinical feature- Maculopapular rash on the trunk, which spreads peripherally

It is non allergic, benign phenomenon

Ampicillin can be administered again in the future

Option B, C & D: Those Drugs are Not Related in Causing Rash In Infectious Mononucleosis patients.

Key Takeaway:

Infectious Mononucleosis Patient on Receiving Ampicillin Characteristic Centripetal Maculopapular Rash Occurs. It's Benign Phenomenon and Ampicillin can be administered in Future.

questions.text: Erythema multiforme is seen in_
questions.solution:
Classical lesion of erythema multiforme is target lesion / bull's eye lesion

It has three concentric areas.

Etiology:

-Idiopathic

-VIral infection (Herpes simplex, mycoplasma)

-Drugs (NSAIDS, Sulfonamides, antiepileptics, antibiotics,antimalarials)

Symptoms

  • Target-like lesions: The rash often appears as target-like lesions with three distinct zones of color.
  • Itching and burning: The lesions can be itchy and burning.
  • Fever and malaise: In severe cases, EM may be accompanied by fever, fatigue, and joint pain.

Treatment: Conservative

Option A: Celiac Disease is associated with Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Option B: ITP Have Characteristics Purpura lesions.

Option D: Leukemia May Present with multiple tender erythematous skin lesions due to Neutrophilic Infiltration aka Sweet Syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

Erythema multiforme:

-Cutaneous Reaction

-MC Infection trigger: HSV 1 infection.

-Lesion: Target lesions. (Site: Palms and soles).

questions.text: Lesion shown in the image is associated with which of the following skin cancer?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous horn, or cornu cutaneum, is a relatively uncommon, hyperkeratotic epithelial lesion resembling an animal horn.

Actinic keratoses are the most common premalignant primary cause of cutaneous horn, whereas squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common malignant cause.

Option B: Melanoma is a tumor produced by the malignant transformation of melanocytes.

Option C: BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule with surface telangiectasia. The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving the borders a rolled or rodent ulcer appearance. The most common sites for nodular basal cells are the face, especially the nose, cheeks, forehead, nasolabial folds, and eyelids.

Option D: Sarcoma is Tumor of connective / Non epithelial tissues.

Key Takeaway:

Cutaneous Horn, Hyperkeratotic epithelial lesion Being Premalignant May give rise to Squamous cell Carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Melanoma, also redundantly known as malignant melanoma, is a type of skin cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes.

A is for Asymmetry.

B is for Border. Melanoma borders tend to be uneven and may have scalloped or notched edges.

C is for Color. Multiple colors are a warning sign.

D is for Diameter: if the size of the lesion is 6 mm or larger.

E is for Evolving. Any change in size, shape, color or elevation, or any new symptom in it, such as bleeding, itching or crusting, may be a warning sign of melanoma.

Option B:

BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule with surface telangiectasia. The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving the borders a rolled or rodent ulcer appearance. The most common sites for nodular basal cells are the face, especially the nose, cheeks, forehead, nasolabial folds, and eyelids.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma has a precursor lesion, actinic keratosis, which exhibits tumor progression. Primary risk factor for the development of actinic keratoses and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is UV solar radiation.

Option D: Nevus is benign, exophytic, usually pigmented congenital lesion of skin or mucosa composed of focal collection of rounded melanocytes.

Key Takeaway:

Malignant Melanoma ABCDE

  • Asymmetrical
  • Border Irregular
  • Color Changes
  • Diameter greater than 6mm
  • Evolution in size & shape.

questions.text: 60 year old female presented with skin lesion over face since 5 years. Patient is farmer by occupation. What will be diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The prime etiological factor in the development of basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV light, particularly the UVB wavelengths,

Many clinical variants of BCC exist, but the most recognized types are superficial, nodular, and morphea-like BCC. Nodular BCC is the most common.

BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule with surface telangiectasia.

The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving the borders a rolled or rodent ulcer appearance.

The most common sites for nodular basal cells are the face, especially the nose, cheeks, forehead, nasolabial folds, and eyelids.

The characteristic feature seen in BCCs is islands or nests of basaloid cells, with cells palisading at the periphery in a haphazard arrangement in the centers of the islands. Each of these small pleomorphic cells is composed of a basophilic nucleus without a discernible nucleolus and scanty cytoplasm.

Option B: Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade, rapidly growing, 1 to 2 cm dome-shaped skin tumor with a centralized keratinous plug.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma, the second most common form of skin cancer, is caused by the cumulative exposure of skin to UV light. It arises in a background of sun-damaged skin often from precursor lesions called actinic keratoses. The color varies from flesh toned to erythematous with variable degrees of scale, crusting, ulceration, and hyperkeratosis.

Option D: A melanoma is a tumor produced by the malignant transformation of melanocytes.

The 4 major types of melanoma, classified according to growth pattern, are as follows:

  • Superficial spreading melanoma
  • Nodular melanoma
  • Lentigo maligna
  • Acral lentiginous melanoma

Key Takeaway:

Basal Cell Carcinoma

  • Etiology - UV Radiation
  • 4 types - Nodular MC
  • O/E - Shiny pink nodule with surface telengctesia.
  • Histopath - Basaloid cells with peripheral Palisading

questions.text: A 65 year old patient presents with erosions on nasolabial area with history of local erosion. The histology is as shown. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histology shows nests and lobules of basaloid cell with peripheral palisading. Patient of elderly age group presents with erosions on nasolabial area suggests rodent ulcer. Clinicopathological correlation suggest diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma


Option A: SCC shows squamous cell with keratin pearls in histology

Option C: Melanoma biopsy shows melanin Pigments.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides shows pautrier's microabscess and epidermotropism.

Key Takeaway:

Basal Cell Carcinoma

  • Etiology - UV Radiation
  • 4 types - Nodular MC
  • O/E - Shiny pink nodule with surface telengctesia.
  • Histopath - Basaloid cells with peripheral Palisading

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic skin finding of Juvenile Dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria for cutaneous dermatomyositis:

  • Presence of two major criteria or one major and two minor criteria and
  • Skin biopsy changes consistent with cutaneous dermatomyositis

MAJOR CRITERIA

Heliotrope sign

Gottron papules

Gottron sign

MINOR CRITERIA

Macular violaceous erythema involving (each area counts as a minor criterion)

Malar eminences of face, forehead or chin

V area of neck or upper chest (V sign)

Posterior neck or posterior shoulders (shawl sign)

Extensor surfaces of arms or forearms

Linear streaking overlying extensor tendons of dorsal hands

Periungual skin

Lateral thighs or hips (Holster sign)

Medial malleoli

Nail fold capillary telangiectasia, hemorrhage-infarct

Poikiloderma

Mechanic's hands

Cuatenous ulcers

Option A & B:Malar rash and photosensitivity are features of SLE

Option C: Nail bed capillaries are features of systemic sclerosis

questions.text: A 35 year old female with history of fever, photosensitivity, erythematous rash sparing nasolabial fold presents to OPD. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Female with history of fever, rash sparing nasolabial fold, photosensitivity and joint pain suggest diagnosis of SLE.

Heliotrope rash is another differential diagnosis of malar rash of SLE. It is violaceous in colour, involves eyelid and not characteristically spares nasolabial fold.It is feature of Dermatomyositis

Melasma:


Brown coloured pigmentation over malar area, nose, forehead or mandibular area. Not associated with systemic complaints.

Rosacea:


Erythema, telengiectasia erythematous/ papulopustular lesions over convex areas of face like cheek, chin or nose.

Key takeaway:

Female with history of fever, rash sparing nasolabial fold, photosensitivity and joint pain suggest diagnosis of SLE

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient presented with scaly lesion over face, ear and scalp since 2 years. There was history of joint pain. On removal of the scale from the discoid lesion, horny plugs were seen occupying the hair follicles. What will be treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Removal of the scale from the discoid lesion, horny plugs were seen occupying the hair follicles suggestive of "carpet tack sign/ tin tack sign/"

Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is the most prevalent type of chronic lupus erythematosus. Lesions are located mainly over the face, scalp, and ears

Carpet tack sign is a characteristic sign of DLE.

Hypopigmented scaly plaques with surrounding hyperpigmented rim are characteristic lesions. Scarring alopecia is common.

Management with oral hydroxychloroquine with topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors.

Option A- Methotrexate

An immunosuppressant used for various autoimmune diseases and conditions, including severe psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis

Option B: Oral steroid

Only in acute flare

Option D- Phototherapy

Lupus patients have photosensitivity, Thus contraindicated

Key takeaway:

  • Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is chronic lupus erythematosus
  • Lesions are located mainly over the face, scalp, and ears.
  • Hypopigmented scaly plaques with surrounding hyperpigmented rim are characteristic lesions
  • Carpet tack sign is a characteristic sign of DLE.

questions.text: A patient present with box shaped appearance on biopsy as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vertical margin in biopsy suggests Sclerosis/ fibrosis due to thickened collagen bundles.

Morphea

  • Localized scleroderma
  • Ill defined depressed plaque with tightening of skin
  • Scalp- Scarring alopecia
  • HPE- Thickened collagen bundles in papillary ane reticular dermis, perivascular inflammation

Option A: Lichen planus- Focal hypergranulosis, Basal cell degeneration (Max joseph space), Saw tooth rete ridges, civatte bodies.

Option B: Lichen amyloidosis- Congo red positive amyloid deposits seen

Option D: Lichen nitidus- Elongated rete ridges adhere to and surround the infiltrate, in a "ball-in-claw"configuration

Key takeaway:

Morphea

  • Localized scleroderma
  • Ill defined depressed plaque with tightening of skin
  • Scalp- Scarring alopecia
  • HPE- Thickened collagen bundles in papillary ane reticular dermis, perivascular inflammation

questions.text: 4 year old male patient presented with fever since 6 days, rash and associated lymph nodes. Oral examination showed strawberry tongue as shown in the image. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a rare childhood disease that causes inflammation in the walls of small-sized and medium sized arteries. It is most often seen in children under the age of 5


Key takeaway:

  • Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a rare childhood disease that causes inflammation in the walls of small-sized and medium sized arteries.
  • Fever, Conjunctivitis, Rash, Hand feet edema, Strawberry tongue.

questions.text: A 7 year old child with fever, erythematous rash, bone pain, X ray skull shows multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils. Image shows immunohistochemistry of S100, CD1a. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH)

  • Age Group: Most common in young children, typically between 1 to 3 years old.
  • Symptoms: The child's symptoms of fever, erythematous rash, bone pain, and the presence of multiple lytic skull lesions are indicative of LCH.
  • Histological Features:
  • The biopsy findings showing prominent nuclear grooves and eosinophils are characteristic.
  • Immunohistochemical markers such as S100 and CD1a support the diagnosis, as LCH cells are positive for these markers and show the presence of Birbeck granules on ultrastructural examination.
  • Systemic Involvement: LCH can lead to osteolytic bone lesions and complications like diabetes insipidus.

Option A- Rosai-Dorfman Disease

  • Characterized primarily by massive, painless bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, often with fever and hypergammaglobulinemia.

Option B- Kimura Disease

  • A benign chronic inflammatory disorder that usually presents with subcutaneous lesions in the head and neck, and sometimes painless cervical lymphadenopathy. It is not associated with bone lesions or systemic symptoms like fever.

Option C- Juvenile Xanthogranuloma

  • Commonly presents with skin nodules in infants and children, primarily on the head and neck. It is characterized by yellowish lesions and Touton giant cells, not lytic bone lesions or systemic symptoms.

Key takeaway:

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH)

  • Age Group: Most common in young children, typically between 1 to 3 years old.
  • Symptoms: The child's symptoms of fever, erythematous rash, bone pain, and the presence of multiple lytic skull lesions are indicative of LCH.
  • Histological Features:
  • The biopsy findings showing prominent nuclear grooves and eosinophils are characteristic.
  • Immunohistochemical markers such as S100 and CD1a support the diagnosis, as LCH cells are positive for these markers and show the presence of Birbeck granules on ultrastructural examination.
  • Systemic Involvement: LCH can lead to osteolytic bone lesions and complications like diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A person was on anti-cancer drug for last 14 days. He developed itchy rash on back as given in image. Which of the following drug is implicated in the causation ?
questions.solution:
The image is showing Bleomycin induced flagellate dermatitis with characteristic intermingled appearance as if it has been whipped.

Mechanism: Bleomycin is an anticancer agent that causes DNA fragmentation. It is metabolized by the enzyme bleomycin hydrolase, which is not present in the skin or lungs, leading to its accumulation in these tissues.

Option B. Doxorubicin: Hand-foot syndrome

Option C. Actinomycin: Acneiform eruptions

Option D. Mitomycin: Palmar desquamation

Key takeaway:

Bleomycin induced Flagellate dermatitis

Characteristic intermingled appearance as if it has been whipped.

Bleomycin is metabolized by the enzyme bleomycin hydrolase, which is not present in the skin or lungs, leading to its accumulation in these tissues.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the patient shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Dermatitis artefacta or factitious dermatitis is a psychocutaneous disorder in which the patients consciously create lesions in skin, hair, nail, or mucosae to satisfy a psychological need, attract attention, or evade responsibility.
  • Bizarre shaped, sized and destructive lesions appearing abruptly.
  • Inaccessible areas are spared.
  • Lesions not conforming to any disease.

Option B. Polymorphic Light Eruption:

This is a photodermatosis that presents as an itchy rash after sun exposure, often on sun-exposed areas, but lesions conform to a specific pattern related to sunlight.

Option C. Contact Dermatitis to Henna: This would typically present with localized erythema, vesicles, or other reactions in areas of contact with henna.

Option D. Vitiligo: This is an autoimmune condition characterized by loss of pigment in patches on the skin. It typically has a well-defined appearance and would not have the destructive nature as seen in dermatitis artefacta.

Key takeaway:

Dermatitis artefacta

  • psychocutaneous disorder
  • patients consciously create lesions in skin, hair, nail, or mucosae to satisfy a psychological need, attract attention, or evade responsibility.
  • Bizarre shaped, sized and destructive lesions appearing abruptly.
  • Inaccessible areas are spared.

questions.text: Malignant Melanoma characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
Melanoma, also redundantly known as malignant melanoma, is a type of skin cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes.

A is for Asymmetry.

B is for Border. Melanoma borders tend to be uneven and may have scalloped or notched edges.

C is for Color. Multiple colors are a warning sign.

D is for Diameter : if the size of the lesion is 6 mm or larger.

E is for Evolving. Any change in size, shape, color or elevation, or any new symptom in it, such as bleeding, itching or crusting, may be a warning sign of melanoma.


Option A, B & C:Asymmetry, Irregular border and Color changes All are Characteristics of Melanoma.

Key Takeaway:

Malignant Melanoma ABCDE

  • Asymmetrical
  • Border Irregular
  • Color Changes
  • Diameter > 6mm
  • Evolution in size & shape.
